IDBFactory.summary: The IDBFactory interface of the IndexedDB API lets applications asynchronously access the indexed databases. The object that implements the interface is window.indexedDB. You open — that is, create and access — and delete a database with this object, and not directly with IDBFactory.

remarks.para:
-Using IndexedDB
-Starting transactions:
-Using transactions:
-Setting a range of keys:
-Retrieving and making changes to your data:
-Using cursors:
-Reference example: To-do Notifications (View the example live).

IDBFactoryDeleteDatabase.summary:
The deleteDatabase() method of the
interface requests the deletion of a database. The method
returns an object immediately, and performs the deletion
operation asynchronously.

remarks.para:
If the database is successfully deleted, then a success event is fired on
the request object returned from this method, with its result set to
undefined. If an error occurs while the database is being deleted, then an
error event is fired on the request object that is returned from this
method.

When deleteDatabase() is called, any other open connections to this
particular database will get a versionchange event.

-Using IndexedDB
-Starting transactions:
-Using transactions:
-Setting a range of keys:
-Retrieving and making changes to your data:
-Using cursors:
-Reference example: To-do Notifications (View the example live).

IDBFactoryDeleteDatabase.returns: A on which subsequent events related to this request are fired.If the operation is successful, the value of the request's property is null.

IDBFactoryCmp.summary:
The cmp() method of the
interface compares two values as keys to determine equality and ordering for IndexedDB
operations, such as storing and iterating.

blockquote.para:
Do not use this method for comparing arbitrary JavaScript
values, because many JavaScript values are either not valid IndexedDB keys (booleans
and objects, for example) or are treated as equivalent IndexedDB keys (for example,
since IndexedDB ignores arrays with non-numeric properties and treats them as empty
arrays, so any non-numeric arrays are treated as equivalent). This throws an exception
if either of the values is not a valid key.

remarks.para:
-Using IndexedDB
-Starting transactions:
-Using transactions:
-Setting a range of keys:
-Retrieving and making changes to your data:
-Using cursors:
-Reference example: To-do Notifications (View the example live).

IDBFactoryCmp.returns:
An integer that indicates the result of the comparison; the table below lists the
possible values and their meanings:
Returned valueDescription
-11st key is less than the 2nd key
01st key is equal to the 2nd key
11st key is greater than the 2nd key

IDBFactoryOpen.summary: The open() method of the interface requests opening a connection to a database.

remarks.para:
The method returns an object immediately, and performs the open operation asynchronously.
If the operation is successful, a success event is fired on the request object that is returned from this method, with its result attribute set to the new object for the connection.
May trigger upgradeneeded, blocked or versionchange events.

-Using IndexedDB
-Browser storage quotas and eviction criteria.
-Starting transactions:
-Using transactions:
-Setting a range of keys:
-Retrieving and making changes to your data:
-Using cursors:
-Reference example: To-do Notifications (View the example live).

IDBFactoryOpen.returns: A object on which subsequent events related to this request are fired.If the operation is successful, the value of the request's property is a object representing the connection to the database.

IDBFactoryDatabases.summary: The databases method of the interface returns a {{jsxref("Promise")}} that fulfills with an array of objects containing the name and version of all the available databases.

remarks.para: This is a snapshot of the databases, intended primarily to allow web applications to check what databases have been created — in order to, for example, clean up databases created by earlier versions of application code.

-Using IndexedDB
-Starting transactions:
-Using transactions:
-Setting a range of keys:
-Retrieving and making changes to your data:
-Using cursors:
-Reference example: To-do Notifications (View the example live).

IDBFactoryDatabases.returns: A that fulfills with an array of objects representing a snapshot of the available databases (or rejects with the error/exceptions below).Each array object has the following properties:Note that the sequence on the returned objects is undefined.
